"Lone man lost at sea" movies are nothing new; "Life of Pi" and "All is Lost" come to mind, among others. But "The Boat" holds its own and adds a seemingly supernatural twist to the proceedings.

This film is virtually plotless. It has no back story or character development, and it doesn't need them. All we see at the beginning is British/Maltese actor Joe Azzopardi, the unnamed protagonist, leaving his apartment in Malta in the morning for a spin in his small motorboat. As he gets out into the Mediterranean sea, a thick fog surrounds him, and he encounters a sailing vessel that is apparently abandoned. The boat is named Aeolus, in reference to the keeper of the winds in Greek mythology.

Securely lashing his motorboat to a couple of cleats, he boards the vessel and finds it abandoned. His attempts to report the vessel on the ship's radio fails to raise any response.

Then the weirdness starts. His motorboat vanishes. He gets locked in the bathroom for half an hour (No, you won't lose interest, guaranteed) while the boat collides with a huge ship and starts taking on water. Then, the boat, on auto-pilot which can't be turned off, starts heading into a massive storm.

As he deals with one obstacle after another, it becomes apparent that someone or something is out to get him. Is the boat haunted? Far be it from me to report any further.

A film with only one actor presents challenges. There is a lot of pressure on the director, the screenwriter, and of course, the actor to hold our interest. I'm happy to report that in its 100 minute running time, "The Boat" will keep you transfixed. It's that good. The direction is skillful and the cinematography is crisp and vivid. Azzopardi is believable and sympathetic, even though we know nothing about him. He's frustrated and scared, but he pragmatically solves the issues that confront him. His dilemma is Sisyphean: As soon as one disaster is taken care of, another one pops up immediately. 

Movies like this can only end one of two ways: The protagonist either dies or he survives. I'm not spoiling anything by telling you that he survives, but the ending, rather than being overwrought and dramatic, is flat out spooky. I found it perfect. When this film is over, we've learned nothing about Azzopardi's character, and we've learned nothing about the sailboat, other than it's definitely not your normal vessel.

As a bonus, you'll learn a lot about the technical aspects of sailboats. On the other hand, you may never want to get on a boat again. And watching this film may cause you to develop a phobia of doorknobs.

If you know sailing, you'll appreciate this movie because of the worst-case-scenario for sailing alone. I found the storyline engrossing and compelling from the very beginning. A man takes his small boat out and bumps into a seemingly abandoned sailboat. A very believable and likable character, the man is gradually sucked into an increasingly disastrous situation and I really felt for him.

I loved the lack of dialogue as it follows just one character, it's all about the action and the music was perfect for the suspense. It was the perfect length of movie, although I would be interested to see more about this supernatural boat.

I liked this movie. It's not for everyone because it's not that reach out and grab you kind of horror. I believe that the boat represents a capitalistic society (hence the yact) that's driven by greed. Unnecessary luxuries aren't needed to enjoy life. You have to work extra hard to get those things, then struggle to keep them. The boat taking over may have been a metaphor for bill collectors. It's hard getting out of their grasp. He was the only person who left the city, got blinded by the fog, and was lost at sea for a time. Everyone else fished from the shore. The simple life was all that he needed to be happy. In the end, he was relieved to be back where he started. It can be scary being out on your own with no one else to help you. Usually, there's safety in numbers. The boat ominously waiting at the end served as a reminder to be happy with what you have...Oh, and to mind your own business because had he not been nosey in the first place, the boat just may have left him alone.üòÇüòÇ
